title-group.article-title: Propagation of Rayleigh waves in magneto-thermo-elastic half-space of a homogeneous orthotropic material under the effect of rotation, initial stress and gravity field

article-meta.aff: 1Math Department, Faculty of Science, Taif University, Saudi Arabia
2Math Department, Faculty of Science, Qena, Egypt
3Math Department, Faculty of Science, Umm Al-Qura University, Saudi Arabia
4Math Department, Faculty of Science, Sohag University, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: AM Abd-Alla, Maths Department, Faculty of Science, Taif University, Taif 888, Saudi Arabia Email: mohmrram@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The propagation of magneto-thermoelastic plane waves in an initially stressed, homogeneous orthotropic, conducting half-space under a magnetic field, rotation and gravity field have been investigated. The generalized theory of thermoelasticity is employed, by assuming the mechanical behavior as dynamic, to study the problem. The Lame’s potential is used to obtain the frequency equation that determines the velocity of Rayleigh waves that obtained as a real part and the attenuation coefficient as an imaginary part under the rotation, magnetic field, initial stress and gravity field. Numerical results have been given and illustrated graphically for each case considered. Dispersion curves of wave propagation are represented graphically in different theories of thermoelasticity. The results indicate that the effect of rotation, initial stress and gravity field are very pronounced. Comparison is made with the results predicted by the theory of thermoelasticity in the absence of rotation, initial stress and gravity field.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: There are numerous studies on the propagation of Rayleigh waves. The propagation of waves in thermoelastic materials has many applications in various fields of science and technology, atomic physics, industrial engineering, thermal power plants, submarine structures, pressure vessels, aerospace, chemical pipes and metallurgy.

The effect of rotation on a non-homogeneous composite infinite cylinder of orthotropic material has been illustrated by El-Naggar et al. (1995). The influence of gravity on Rayleigh waves, assuming that the force of gravity creates a type of initial stress of hydrostatic nature and the medium is incompressible is discussed by Biot (1965). Propagation of Rayleigh waves in an elastic half-space of orthotropic material is investigated by Abd-Alla (1999). Abd-Alla et al. (2004) investigated Rayleigh waves in a magnetoelastic half-space of orthotropic material under the influence of initial stress and gravity field. Verma (2002) presented the propagation of waves in layered anisotropic media in generalized thermoelasticity in an arbitrary layered plate. Ponnusamy (2007) discussed the wave propagation in a generalized thermoelastic solid cylinder of arbitrary cross-section. Body wave propagation in rotating thermoelastic media is discussed by Sharma and Grover (2009). Influences of rotation, magnetic field, initial stress, and gravity on Rayleigh waves in a homogeneous orthotropic elastic half-space is discussed by Abd-Alla et al. (2011). Abd-Alla and Abo-Dahab (2009) investigated time-harmonic sources in a generalized magneto-thermo-viscoelastic continuum with and without energy dissipation.

The present work deals with the problem of wave propagation in a homogeneous orthotropic, thermoelastic medium under the effect of initial stress, magnetic field, rotation and gravity field. For the wave equations which are satisfied by the displacement potentials φ and ψ, we obtained the frequency equation that determines the velocity of the surface wave and attenuation coefficient, and discussed some particular cases. The results obtained are calculated numerically and then presented graphically.

sec.title: 2. Formulation of the problem
sec.p: Let us consider that the medium is a perfect electric conductor and use the linearized Maxwell equations governing the electromagnetic field, taking into account absence of the displacement current SI as (Roychoudhuri and Banjee, 1986): (1)J=curlh,-μe∂h∂t=curlE,divh=0,divE=0E=-μe(∂u∂t×H0)h=curl(u×H0) where, (2)H=H0+h,H0=(0,H0,0). where h is the perturbed magnetic field over the primary magnetic field, E is the electric intensity, J is the electric current density, μe is the magnetic permeability, H is the constant primary magnetic field and u is the displacement vector.

We consider an orthotropic elastic solid under constant primary magnetic field H0 acting on the y-axis, gravity field g and an initial compression P along the x direction. We take a set of orthogonal Cartesian axes oxyz, the origin o being any point of the boundary and oz pointing normally to the medium and the x-axis being positive along the direction of Rayleigh wave propagation. At a great distance from the center of the disturbance, the wave is then two-dimensional and is polarized in the (x, z) plane, by which we mean that the component of displacement in the x and z directions; viz., u and w are not zero, but v = 0 and u and w are independent of y. The elastic medium is rotating uniformly with an angular velocity Ω¯=Ωn¯, where n¯ is a unit vector representing the direction of the axis of rotation. The displacement equation of motion in the rotating frame has two additional term centripetal acceleration, Ω×(Ω×u) due to time varying motion only and 2Ω×u· is the dynamic displacement vector and Ω=(0,Ω,0).

If g is the acceleration due to gravity, then the components of body forces are X = 0, Z = −g, and the initial stress field due to gravity is hydrostatic, the states of initial stress τij are given as (Datta, 1986) (3)τ11=τ33=τ,τ13=0

The equilibrium conditions of the initial stress field (Datta, 1986) (4)∂τ∂x=0,∂τ∂z-ρg=0,
(5)τij,i+Fj=ρ[u··+{Ω×(Ω×u)}+(2Ω×u·)]j, i,j=1,2,3

The heat conduction equation is given by Tanka et al. (1995) as the form (6)Tii=2ρsδ1+δ2∂∂t(1+τ2∂∂t)T+(ν1+ν3)T0δ1+δ2∂∂t ×(1+τ2∂∂t)∇¯·u,i=1,2,3 where F is the Lorentz’s body forces vector, s is the specific heat of the material per unit mass, α1 and α2 are the thermal expansion coefficients, γ=αt(3λ+2μ), δ1 and δ2 are the thermal conductivity, λ and μ are Lame elastic constants, τ is a function of depth, τ1 and τ2 are thermal relaxation parameter, θ is the absolute temperature, ρ is density of the material, T0 is reference temperature solid, T is temperature difference (θ-T0).

These two terms do not appear in the equations for non-rotating media. The equation of motion in two-dimensions (x, z) reduces to (Biot, 1965): (7)∂τ11∂x+∂τ31∂z+P∂ω13∂z-ρg∂w∂x+Fx =ρ[∂2u∂t2+2Ω∂w∂t-Ω2u],
(8)∂τ13∂x+∂τ33∂z+P∂ω13∂x+ρg∂u∂x+Fz =ρ[∂2w∂t2-2Ω∂u∂t-Ω2w].

The Lorentz’s body forces vector (9)(Fx,Fy,Fz)=μeH02([∂2u∂x2+∂2w∂x∂z],0,[∂2u∂x∂z+∂2w∂z2]) in this case can be written as follows: The stress (10)τ11=(c11+P)∂u∂x+(c13+P)∂w∂z-ν1(1+τ1∂∂t)T,τ33=c13∂u∂x+c33∂w∂z-ν3(1+τ1∂∂t)T,τ13=c44(∂u∂z+∂w∂x),ν1=(c11+c12)α1+c13α2,ν3=2c13α1+c33α2 where, ωij=12(ui,j-uj,i), cij are the stiffness tensor components in the contraction notation so that c12=c22=c23=0, since the problem is treated in two-dimensions (x, z), and assumption with c44=12(c11-c13).

Substituting equations (10) into equations (7) and (8), becomes (11)(c11+P)[2∂2u∂x2+∂2w∂x∂z+∂2u∂z2]+c13[∂2w∂x∂z-∂2u∂z2] -2ρg∂w∂x+2μeH02[∂2u∂x2+∂2w∂x∂z]-2ν1(1+τ1∂∂t)∂T∂x =2ρ[∂2u∂t2+2Ω∂w∂t-Ω2u],
(12)c11[∂2u∂x∂z+∂2w∂x2]+(c13+P)[∂2u∂x∂z-∂2w∂x2]+2c33∂2w∂z2 +2ρg∂u∂x+2μeH02[∂2u∂x∂z+∂2w∂z2]-2ν3(1+τ1∂∂t)∂T∂z =2ρ[∂2w∂t2-2Ω∂u∂t-Ω2w].

Using Helmholtz’s theorem (Misra et al., 1994), the displacement vector u can be written in the displacement potentials φ and ψ form, as (13)u=gradφ+curlψ,ψ=(0,ψ,0) which reduces to (14)u=∂φ∂x-∂ψ∂z, w=∂φ∂z+∂ψ∂x.

Substituting equation (14) into equations (11) and (12) respectively brings (15)[c11+P+μeH02]∇2φ-ρg∂ψ∂x-ν1(1+τ1∂∂t)T =ρ[∂2φ∂t2+2Ω∂ψ∂t-Ω2φ],
(16)[c11+P-c13]∇2ψ+ρg∂φ∂x=2ρ[∂2ψ∂t2-2Ω∂φ∂t-Ω2ψ] and (17)c11[∂2ψ∂x2-∂2ψ∂z2]-(c13+P)∇2ψ+2c33∂2ψ∂z2+2ρg∂φ∂x =2ρ[∂2ψ∂t2-2Ω∂φ∂t-Ω2ψ],
(18)c11∂2φ∂x2+c33∂2φ∂z2-ρg∂ψ∂x+μeH02∇2φ-ν3(1+τ1∂∂t)T =ρ[∂2φ∂t2+2Ω∂ψ∂t-Ω2φ]
Also from equation (14), equation (6) becomes (19)∇2T=2ρsδ1+δ2∂∂t(1+τ2∂∂t)T+(ν1+ν3)T0δ1+δ2∂∂t ×(1+τ2∂∂t)∇2φ,i=1,2,3 where, ∇2=∂2∂x2+∂2∂z2.

Since the initial compressive wave has been taken in the x-direction, the velocity of the body waves are different in x and z directions. Thus equations (15) and (17) represent the compressive wave along the x and z directions, respectively, and equations (16) and (18) represent the shear wave along those directions respectively.
From equations (15) and (19) by eliminating T, we obtain (20)[∇2-2ρsδ1+δ2∂∂t(1+τ2∂∂t)] ×{α2∇2φ-ρg∂ψ∂x-[∂2φ∂t2+2Ω∂ψ∂t-Ω2φ]}=(ν1+ν3δ1+δ2)2T0(1+τ1∂∂t)∂∂t(1+τ2δ∂∂t)∇2φ where, (21)α2=[c11+P+μeH02]

Since we consider the propagation of Rayleigh waves in the direction of x only, we restrict our attention only to equations (15) and (17), and their solutions take the form (22)φ=f(z)eiξ(x-ct),ψ=h(z)eiξ(x-ct).

Substituting from equation (22) into equations (17) and (20), we obtain (23)[D4+m1D2+m2]f+[m3+m4D2]h=0,
(24)D2h+L1h+L2f=0 where, (25)τ1*=1-iξcτ1,τ2*=1-iξcτ2,τδ=1-iξcδτ1,m1=n1α2+Kn3-n2Kα2,m2=n1n3+ξ2n2Kα2,m3=n1n4Kα2,m4=1α2,n1=-ξ2K+iξcρsτ2*,n2=-iγ2T0τ1*τδξc,n3=ξ2ρc2+ρΩ2-ξ2α2,n4=ρgξ2+2iρΩξc,L1=ξ2(c13+P-c11+2ρc2+2ρΩ2)2c33-P-c11-c13,L2=2iρξ(g-2Ωc)2c33-P-c11-c13,K=δ1+δ22.
From equations (24) and (25), we get (26)[D6+m1*D4+m2*D2+m3*]h=0 where, (27)m1*=m1+L1,m2*=m2+m1L1-m4L2,m3*=m2(L1-L2).
Equation (2.26) represents the initial integral equation of order six, and has six roots, i.e., (28)λ6+m1*λ4+m2*λ2+m3*=0.

Hence, the solutions of equations (19), (23) and (24) in the form (29)h(z)=∑j=13[Ajeiξλjz+Bje-iξλjz],
(30)f(z)=∑j=13[NjAjeiξλjz+NjBje-iξλjz],
(31)T=1γτ1*∑j=13[-Nj(α2ξ2+α2ξ2λ12-ρξ2c2+ρΩ2) -ρ(igξ-2iΩξc)]×[Ajeiξλjz+Bje-iξλjz] where, AjandBj are constants, and (32)Nj=ξ2λj2-L1L2,j=1,2,3.
Since the displacement at z→∞ should be zero for Rayleigh waves. Hence λ1,λ2andλ3 are taken to be imaginary, and the constant Aj must vanish.

Therefore, from equation (22) the final form of the solutions as: (33)φ=∑j=13[NjBje-iξλjz]eiξ(x-ct),
(34)ψ=∑j=13[Bje-iξλjz]eiξ(x-ct),
(35)T=1γτ1*∑j=13[-Nj(α2ξ2+α2ξ2λj2-ρξ2c2+ρΩ2) -ρ(igξ-2iΩξc)]×[Bje-iξλjz]eiξ(x-ct).

sec.title: 3. Boundary conditions and discussion
sec.p:
The boundary conditions are that the plane z = 0 is free from stresses and thermal insulated, i.e., (36)τ13+τ¯13=0τ33+τ¯33=0∂T∂z=0}atz=0 where, (37)τ13=12(c11-c13)(2∂2φ∂x∂z-∂2ψ∂z2+∂2ψ∂x2),
(38)τ33=c13∂2φ∂x2+c33∂2φ∂z2+(c33-c13)∂2ψ∂x∂z, and the Maxwell’s electro-magnetic stress tensor τ¯ij is given by (39)τ¯ij=μe[Hihj+Hjhi-(H.h)δij],i,j=1,2,3 which take the forms (40)τ¯13=0,τ¯33=μeH02∇2φ
Then (41)(2∂2φ∂x∂z-∂2ψ∂z2+∂2ψ∂x2)=0,c13∂2φ∂x2+c33∂2φ∂z2+(c33-c13)∂2ψ∂x∂z +μeH02(∂2φ∂x2+∂2φ∂z2)=0,∂∂z[-Nj(α2ξ2+α2ξ2λj2-ρξ2c2+ρΩ2) -ρ(igξ-2iΩξc)]×[Bje-iξλjz]eiξ(x-ct)=0}atz=0
From equation (41) one may obtain (42)[iξ(1-iξλj2+2iξcλjNj)]Bj=0,[Nj(c13+c33λj2+μeH02) -λj(c33-c13-λj)]Bj=0,[-Nj(α2ξ2+α2ξ2λj2-ρξ2c2+ρΩ2) -ρ(igξ-2iΩξc)]Bj=0} j=1,2,3.

To determine the constants B1, B2 and B3, it is necessary that the determinant of the constants coefficients must vanish, i.e., (43)|η1ν1β1η2ν2β2η3ν3β3|=0, where, (44)ηj=iξ(1-iξλj2+2iξcλjNj),νj=Nj(c13+c33λj2+μeH02)-λj(c33-c13-λj),βj=[-Nj(α2ξ2+α2ξ2λj2-ρξ2c2+ρΩ2) -ρ(igξ-2iΩξc)]}

Equation (43) determines the Rayleigh surface waves under the influences of the Earth’s gravity, rotation, and magnetic field with an initial compression in thermo orthotropic elastic solid medium, from determined this equation we found that it has complex roots. The real part (Re) gives the velocity of Rayleigh waves and the imaginary part (Im) gives the attenuation coefficient.

sec.title: 4. Numerical results and discussions
sec.p:
We discuss this case and special cases in two models as follows:
(I) LS-model (τ1=0,τ2>0,δ=1)
(II) GL-model (τ1≥τ2>0,δ=0).

The discussion is made clear in Figures 1 to 4. The material chosen for this purpose of carbon steel, the physical data for which is given below as isotropic material (Sharma and Pal, 2004). λ=9.3×1010Nm-1, μ=8.4×1010Nm-1,T0=293.1k,μe=0.2, s=6.4×102JKg-1deg-1,αt=13.2×10-6deg-1, K=50Wm-1k-1. Figure 1.
(a) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to the initial stress; (b) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to the initial stress. Figure 2.
(a) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,P,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to wave number; (b) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,P,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to wave number. Figure 3.
(a) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity respect to the initial stress; (b) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on attenuation coefficient respect to the initial stress. Figure 4.
(a) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,P,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity respect to wave number; (b) Effects of Ω,H0,ρ,g,P,τ2 on attenuation coefficient respect to wave number. Figure 5.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to the initial stress; (b) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to the initial stress.
Figure 6.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,p,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to wave number; (b) Effects of ρ,g,p,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to wave number.
Figure 7.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to the initial stress; (b) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to the initial stress.
For computational work, if the medium is orthotropic, we take c11=2.694,c13=0.661,c33=2.363.

If the medium is isotropic (see Sadd, 2005), we take c11=c33=λ+2μ,c13=λ.
(I) LS-model: (τ1=0,τ2>0,δ=1)

sec.title: 5. Special cases
sec.p:
(i) If the magnetic field and Ω are neglected, equation (44) reduces to
(45)|η'1ν'1β'1η'2ν'2β'2η'3ν'3β'3|=0, where, (46)η'j=iξ(1-iξλj2+2iξcλjN'j)ν'j=N'j(c13+c33λj2+μeH02)-λj(c33-c13-λj)β'j=-[N'j(α2ξ2+α2ξ2λj2-ρξ2c2)+iρgξ].},
(47)N'j=ξ2λj2-L'1L'2j=1,2,3
(48)L'1=ξ2(c13+P-c11+2ρc2)2c33-P-c11-c13,L'2=2iρξg2c33-P-c11-c13.

The discussion is made clear in Figures 5 to 8.
(I) LS-model: (τ1=0,τ2>0,δ=1).
(II) GL-model: (τ1≥τ2>0,δ=0), τ1=2τ2.
(ii) If the medium is isotropic, (see, equation (14)), then
(49)c11,c33=λ+2μ,c13=λ,c44=μ and if H0=0,Ω=0, equation (45) reduces to (50)|η1*ν1*β1*η2*ν2*β2*η3*ν3*β3*|=0, where, (51)ηj*=iξ(1-iξλj2+2iξcλjNj*)νj*=Nj*(λ+(λ+2μ)λj2)-λj(2μ-λj)βj*=-[Nj*(ξ2(λ+2μ+P)(1+λj2)-ρξ2c2)+iρgξ]},
(52)Nj*=ξ2λj2-L1*L2*j=1,2,3
(53)L1*=ξ2(P-2(μ+ρc2))2μ-P,L2*=2iρξg2μ-P.
Equation (50) determines the Rayleigh surface waves in an isotropic thermoelastic medium under the effect of gravity and initial stress.

The discussion is made clear in Figures 9 to 12.
(I) LS-model: (τ1=0,τ2>0,δ=1).
(II) GL-model: (τ1≥τ2>0,δ=0),τ1=2τ2.
Figure 8.
(a) Effects of ρ,P,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to wave number; (b) Effects of ρ,g,P,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to wave number.
Figure 9.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to the initial stress; (b) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to the initial stress. Figure 10.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,P,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to wave number; (b) Effects of ρ,g,p,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to wave number. Figure 11.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to the initial stress; (b) Effects of ρ,g,ξ,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to the initial stress. Figure 12.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,P,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to wave number; (b) Effects of ρ,g,P,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to wave number.

Equation (55) determines the Rayleigh surface waves in an isotropic thermoelastic medium under the effect of gravity. The discussion is made clear in Figures 13 and 14.
(I) LS-model: (τ1=0,τ2>0,δ=1).
(II) GL-model: (τ1≥τ2>0,δ=0),τ1=2τ2.
Figure 13.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to wave number; (b) Effects of ρ,g,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to wave number.
Figure 14.
(a) Effects of ρ,g,τ2 on Rayleigh wave velocity with respect to wave number; (b) Effects of ρ,g,τ2 on attenuation coefficient with respect to wave number.

sec.title: 6. Numerical results and discussions
sec.p: The material chosen for this purpose was carbon steel, the physical data for which is given below (Sharma and Mohinder, 2004). (58)λ=9.3×1010Nm-1, μ=8.4×1010Nm-1,T0=293.1k,μe=0.2, s=6.4×102JKg-1deg-1,αt=13.2×10-6deg-1, K=50Wm-1k-1.
For computational work, if the medium is orthotropic, we take c11=2.694,c13=0.661,c33=2.363.
If the medium is isotropic (see Sadd, 2005), we take (59)c11,c33=λ+2μ,c13=λ

sec.title: 6.1. General case
sec.p: For LS-model: Figure 1(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of rotation, magnetic field, density, gravity field, and thermal relaxation time with respect to the initial stress, we find that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) decreased with increasing values of Ω and H0, and increased with increasing values ρ,gandξ, while vacillation takes place of values of (Re) under effect of τ2, i.e., the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing values of τ2 and with increasing values of p respectively. Figure 1(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under effect of rotation, magnetic field, density, gravity field, wave number and thermal relaxation time with respect to the initial stress, the values of (Im) increased and decreased with increasing values of Ω, H0, and p respectively, while the values (Im) decreased and increased with increasing values p,g and ξ respectively. Also, the values of (Im) decreased with increasing values τ2.

Figure 2(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of Ω,H0,ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to the wave number, the values of (Re) increased and decreased with increasing values of Ω, H0, and ξ respectively, vice versa with increased τ2, also, the values (Re) take one curve increased with increasing ξ with different values of ρ. Also the value of (Re) increased with increasing pandg. Figure 2(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of Ω,H0,ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to the wave number, the values of (Im) decreased and increased with increasing values of Ω and H0, while it decreases with increasing τ2, also, the values of (Im) decreased with increasing values of ρ,gandp.

For GL-model: Figure 3(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of Ω,H0,ρ,g,ξandτ2 with respect to initial stress, the values of (Re) increased and decreased with increasing values of Ω and H0, while the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing ρ,g,ξ and τ2 respectively. Figure 3(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of Ω,H0,ρ,g,ξandτ2 with respect to initial stress, we find values of (Im) increased with increasing values of Ω and H0, while the values of (Im) decreased with increasing values of ρ,g,ξandτ2.

Figure 4(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of Ω,H0,ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Re) increased and decreased with increasing values of Ω and H0, while it decreases with increasing τ2, also, the values of (Re) increased with increasing gandp, and become one curve is increased with increasing wave number at another value of ρ. Figure 4(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of Ω,H0,ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Im) decreased and increased with increasing values of Ω and H0, while it decreases with increasing τ2, also, the values of (Im) decreased with increasing values of ρ,gandp.

sec.title: 6.2. Special cases

list-item.p: (i) If the magnetic field and rotation are neglected:

sec.p: For LS-model: Figure 5(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,ξandτ2 with respect to initial stress, the values of (Re) increased and decreased with increasing values of ρandξ, while it decreases with increasing g, also the values of (Re) decreased with increasing τ2. Figure 5(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to initial stress, the values of (Im) decreased and increased with increasing values of ρ,ξandτ2, while that it decreases with increasing g.

Figure 6(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing values of g, while contrary with increased τ2, also, the value of (Re) it decreases with increasing values of ρandp. Figure 6(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Im) increased and decreased with increasing values of g, while it decreases with increasing τ2, also, the values of (Im) increased with increasing values of ρandp.

For GL-model: Figure 7(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,ξandτ2 with respect to initial stress, we find the values of (Re) decreased with increasing values of ρ,ξandτ2, while the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing g. Figure 7(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,ξandτ2 with respect to initial stress, the values of (Im) decreased and increased with increasing values of ρ,ξandτ2, while it decreases with increasing g.

Figure 8(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,p and τ2 with respect to wave number, we find the values of (Re) decreased with increasing values of ρ and p, the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing g, while that contrary with increased τ2. Figure 8(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,p and τ2 with respect to wave number, we find the values of (Im) increased with increasing values of ρ and p, the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing g, while it decreases with increasing τ2.
(ii) If the medium is isotropic:

For LS-model: Figure 9(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,ξ and τ2 with respect to initial stress, we find the values of (Re) increased with increasing values of ρ and g, while it decreases with increasing values of ξ and τ2. Figure 9(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,ξ and τ2 with respect to initial stress, we find the values of (Im) at maximal values of com off middle between the small values of ρ, while the values of (Im) increased with increasing values of ξ and τ2, while it decreases with increasing g.

Figure 10(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, we find the values of (Re) at maximal value of com off middle between the small values of ρ, while vacillation of values of (Re) at effect gandτ2, i.e., the value of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing g, while that it decreases with increasing τ2, also, the values of (Re) become one curve decreased with increasing values of wave number. Figure 10(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Im) increased and decreased with increasing ρ, while the value of (Im) at maximal value at ξ=7 for the small values of g, also, the values of (Im) increased with increasing value of τ2 and at effect p the values of (Im) become one curve decreased with increasing values of wave number.

For GL-model: Figure 11(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,ξandτ2 with respect to initial stress, we find the values of (Re) increased with increasing values of ρandg, while that contrary with increased values of ξandτ2. Figure 11(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,ξandτ2 with respect to initial stress, we find the values of (Im) decreased with increasing values of ρandg, while it decreases with increasing τ2, also the values of (Im) at maximal values of com off middle between the small values of ξ.

Figure 12(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing ρ, and the values of (Re) decreased with increasing values of g, while the values of (Re) increased with increasing values of τ2, and the value of (Re) becoming one curve increased at different values of pandξ. Figure 12(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,g,pandτ2 with respect to wave number, we find the value of (Im) increased with increasing values of ρandg, while it decreases with increasing τ2, also, the value of (Im) become one curve decreased at different values of pandξ.
(iii) If the medium is isotropic and the initial stress is neglected:

For LS-model: Figure 13(a) shows that the velocity of Rayleigh waves (Re) under the effect of ρ,gandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Re) decreased and increased with increasing g, while it decreases with increasing τ2, also, the values of (Re) at the maximal values of com off middle between the small values of ρ. Figure 13(b) shows that the attenuation coefficient (Im) under the effect of ρ,gandτ2 with respect to wave number, the values of (Im) increased and decreased with increasing values of ρ, while the values of (Im) at maximum value at ξ=7 for the small values of g, also, the value of (Im) increased with decreasing τ2.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p:
Due to the complicated nature of the governing equations for propagation of waves in magneto-thermo-elastic half-space, the work done in this field has unfortunately been limited. The method used in this study provides a successful Lame’s potential in dealing with such problems. This potential gives exact solutions in the half-space domain without any assumed restrictions on the actual physical quantities that appear in the governing equations of the problem considered. Important phenomena are observed in all these computations:
It was found that for large values the coupled and the generalized give close results. The case is quite different when we consider a small value of rotation. The coupled theory predicts infinite speeds of wave propagation. The solutions obtained in the context of LS and GN theory, however, exhibit the behavior of finite speeds of wave propagation.
By comparing Figures 1 to 13 for the LS-model with the Figures for the GL-model, it was found that the Rayleigh wave has the same behavior in both media. Numerical values of the Rayleigh wave in orthotropic material are large in comparison with those in isotropic material due to the influences of the magnetic field, initial stress, rotation and gravity field.
The results presented in this paper should prove useful for researchers in material science, for designers of new materials, for low-temperature physicists, and for those working on the development of a theory of hyperbolic propagation of waves. Although the effect of initial stress is observed to be quite small in Rayleigh wave velocity, a significant effect is observed in the magnetic field, rotation and gravity field. The numerical computed results are significantly in agreement with the corresponding analytic results.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
